messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: The Hunger Games is a story by Suzanne Collins.
It is about a cruel TV game.
Teenagers must fight, and only one can live.

One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins changed TV channels.
It was during the US war in Iraq.
On TV, she saw only two kinds of shows.
She saw young people trying to win one million dollars.
And she saw news about the war.
These two things mixed in her mind.
They felt wrong together.
So she got the idea for The Hunger Games.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7213 is below the required 0.75.
- The summary sentence “It is about a cruel TV game” adds interpretation not present in the original text.
- Starting with a summary shifts focus away from the original event of flipping TV channels in 2003.
Suggestion: Remove the added summary and use original phrasing such as “reality programmes of young people competing to win a million dollars” to preserve the core message.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins changed TV channels.
It was during the US war in Iraq.
She found only two kinds of programmes.
She saw reality programmes of young people.
They competed to win a million dollars.
She also saw news about the war.
These two things started to mix in her mind.
They felt wrong together.
Then she got the idea for The Hunger Games.
The Hunger Games is a book by Suzanne Collins.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: CEFR Compliance Violation. The text passed factual and meaning checks but fails A2 vocabulary requirements.
- The word reality is classified as B1 level
- The word Hunger (in The Hunger Games) is classified as B1 level
Suggestion: Replace reality with real or true and describe The Hunger Games as a story or book without using the B1 word Hunger. Ensure all words are on an A2 list and use simple expressions only.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins changed TV channels.
It was during the US war in Iraq.
She found only two kinds of TV shows.
She saw shows with young people.
They tried to win one million dollars.
She also saw news about the war.
These two things started to mix in her mind.
They felt wrong together.
Then she got an idea for a new book.
This book is by Suzanne Collins.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7319 is below the required 0.75. Your version changes ‘the US invasion of Iraq’ to ‘the US war in Iraq’, losing the precise reference. It also breaks ‘reality programmes of young people competing to win a million dollars’ into two sentences, diluting the original concept. Suggestion: Restore the phrase ‘US invasion of Iraq’ exactly. Suggestion: Retain ‘reality programmes of young people competing to win a million dollars’ as one unit to preserve the core message.
